items.question: SI.L1-B.1.XII – Flaw Remediation
Flaw Identification Process
How does your company find weaknesses in its systems such as software bugs, missing updates, or security gaps before attackers can exploit them?

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

items.question: Notes / Evidence
items.codingInstructions: Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.

Flaw Identification Process The policy for identifying system flaws and vulnerabilities includes the following methods:

•   Automated Vulnerability Scanning: Regular checks are conducted automatically to identify weaknesses in the system.
•   Vendor Security Notifications and Bulletins: Updates from vendors are monitored to stay informed about any security issues or flaws.
•   Penetration Testing: Security experts perform simulated attacks to uncover potential weaknesses before they can be exploited.
•   Regular Security Assessments: Ongoing reviews are done to assess and identify any flaws or vulnerabilities.
•   Threat Intelligence Feeds: Information is gathered from trusted external sources to stay aware of emerging threats.
•   Incident Response and Forensics: If a security incident occurs, it is analyzed to determine the cause and prevent similar issues in the future.

items.question: SI.L1-B.1.XIV – Update Malicious Code Protection
Update Frequency
How frequently are malicious code protection mechanisms updated?

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

items.question: Notes / Evidence
items.codingInstructions: Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.

Update Frequency – Regularly update malware protection tools and definitions to ensure defense against the latest threats. The following update frequencies are considered:

•   Real-time updates (as available): Updates are applied immediately as new information becomes available.
•   Hourly: Updates are performed every hour to ensure systems remain protected.
•   Daily: Updates are applied once a day to keep security measures up-to-date.
•   Weekly: Updates are conducted on a weekly basis to ensure ongoing protection.
•   Manual updates only: Updates are applied manually when needed.

Update Management Process is the formal procedure for ensuring our malicious code protection systems are always current. It involves the controlled testing, deployment, and verification of updates to defend against the latest threats.

•   Automatic Updates: The system is configured to apply critical security updates automatically as they become available.
•   Centralized Management: A central system manages and deploys updates to all devices, ensuring consistent protection.
•   Update Verification: A process is in place to verify that updates have been successfully installed across all systems.
•   Rollback Plan: A procedure exists to safely roll back or uninstall a problematic update if it causes system issues.
•   Status Notifications: Administrators are automatically notified of update deployments, especially if any failures occur.

items.question: SI.L1-B.1.XV – System & File Scanning
Do you have written policies and procedures that explain how your company scans systems and files for viruses and other malicious software?

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

items.question: Notes / Evidence
items.codingInstructions: Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.

This refers to having official documents — not just informal practices — that spell out:

System scanning policy – how often company computers and servers are scanned for malware (e.g., daily, weekly).

File scanning policy – rules for automatically scanning new files from email, downloads, or USB drives before they are opened.

Scanning procedure – step-by-step instructions for IT staff or employees on how scans are run, monitored, and acted on if threats are found.

Having written documents proves the process is consistent, not left to chance, and is key for compliance.

Anti-Malware Implementation is the process of installing and managing software that protects our systems from malicious software (malware), such as viruses, ransomware, and spyware. These tools are designed to actively detect, block, and remove any harmful code that could damage the system or steal data.

•   Anti-Malware Software Installation: Protective anti-malware software is installed and active on all company systems and devices.
•   Real-time Protection: The software continuously runs in the background, scanning files and activities to block threats as they occur.
•   Automatic Updates: The software automatically updates its threat definitions to protect against the latest malware variants.
•   Scheduled Full Scans: Regular, in-depth scans of the entire system are scheduled to find any dormant or hidden threats.
•   Automated Threat Removal: When malware is detected, it is automatically removed or quarantined by the software to neutralize the threat.

Periodic Scanning Implementation is the process of scheduling automatic, regular security checks on your system. Unlike real-time scanning which is always on, periodic scans perform a deep, comprehensive review at set intervals (e.g., daily or weekly) to find any hidden or dormant threats.

•   Scheduled Scans: Scans are scheduled to run automatically at regular intervals, such as daily, weekly, or monthly, to proactively find hidden threats.
•   Full System Scans: The scan is comprehensive, performing a deep check of all files, programs, and system areas for malicious activity.
•   Automatic Actions: If threats are found, they are automatically quarantined (isolated) or removed by the system to prevent damage.
•   Reporting: A report is generated after each scan, summarizing the results, any threats that were found, and the actions taken.

File integrity monitoring is like a security alarm for your most important system files. It watches critical files (such as system settings, configurations, or security controls) and raises an alert if someone — or something — tries to change them without approval. This helps detect tampering, malware, or insider threats before serious damage is done. For example, if a hacker tries to alter a security file to bypass protections, monitoring would flag it immediately.

Results Handling & Testing refers to the critical process of analyzing scan results and verifying system security. This ensures that any identified threats are dealt with effectively and that security measures are working as intended.

•   Handling Scan Results: After a scan, the system must automatically take action, such as removing harmful files, blocking threats, or alerting administrators.
•   Quarantine and Removal: Threats are either quarantined (isolated) to prevent damage or deleted entirely from the system.
•   Reporting: A report is generated after each scan to summarize the findings, actions taken, and the overall security status.
•   Testing Security Measures: Regular, automated tests are run to verify that security tools are configured correctly and effectively defending against threats.
•   Follow-up Actions: When vulnerabilities are found, a clear process must exist for follow-up actions like applying patches, updating software, or strengthening security configurations.
